title: Log and indexing do not commute correctly with respect to gradient
body_html:
Bug

I encountered an unexpected nan gradient that was rectified by swapping the order of torch.log and an indexing operation [a > 0.]. These ought to commute right

To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

>>> import torch
>>>
>>> a = torch.tensor([0., 1., 2.], requires_grad=True)
>>> l = torch.log(a)[a > 0.].sum()
>>> l.backward()
>>> print(a.grad)
tensor([   nan, 1.0000, 0.5000])
>>> a.grad.data.zero_()
tensor([0., 0., 0.])
>>> l = torch.log(a[a > 0.]).sum()
>>> l.backward()
>>> print(a.grad)
tensor([0.0000, 1.0000, 0.5000])

Expected behavior

The second answer tensor([0.0000, 1.0000, 0.5000]) is the correct gradient, since a[0] is not used in calculating l.

Environment

PyTorch version: 0.4.0 (also tested on 0.4.1/CPU)
Is debug build: No
CUDA used to build PyTorch: 9.1.85

OS: Fedora release 28 (Twenty Eight)
GCC version: (GCC) 8.2.1 20181011 (Red Hat 8.2.1-4)

body:
##  Bug
I encountered an unexpected `nan` gradient that was rectified by swapping the order of `torch.log` and an indexing operation `[a > 0.]`. These ought to commute right

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

```
>>> import torch
>>>
>>> a = torch.tensor([0., 1., 2.], requires_grad=True)
>>> l = torch.log(a)[a > 0.].sum()
>>> l.backward()
>>> print(a.grad)
tensor([   nan, 1.0000, 0.5000])
>>> a.grad.data.zero_()
tensor([0., 0., 0.])
>>> l = torch.log(a[a > 0.]).sum()
>>> l.backward()
>>> print(a.grad)
tensor([0.0000, 1.0000, 0.5000])
```

## Expected behavior

The second answer `tensor([0.0000, 1.0000, 0.5000])` is the correct gradient, since `a[0]` is not used in calculating `l`.
